item.title: 143. How to Set & Hold Boundaries with Melissa Urban | We Can Do Hard Things
item.description: Podcast Description The top (surprising) signs that tell you it’s time to set a boundary. Paying attention to “energy leakage” – when you’re giving out more than you’re getting back. How to set the specific boundaries you need with in-laws, friends, and romantic partners. Scripts for Melissa’s green, yellow, and red system of clear, kind communication in boundary setting. Rethinking boundaries – not as not a response to someone else’s behavior – but as giving voice to your worth and health.

item.title: 142. Codependence: How to Stop Controlling Others with Melody Beattie | We Can Do Hard Things
item.description: Podcast Description The Mother of Codependence shares the difference between healthy and unhealthy helping. The daily practice that helps Melody stop controlling others and “Let Life Happen.” Why no one is able to gaslight you more than you. The one area of life where Codependence is necessary. All four of us surrender to the truth that we will never be Codependent No More. About Melody: A pioneering voice in self-help literature, Melody Beattie is the author of many bestselling books, including Codependent No More – a #1 New York Times bestseller, which has sold over 7 million copies – as well as The Language of Letting Go, Playing It by Heart, The Grief Club, and Beyond Codependency.

item.title: 141. Sara Bareilles: How to Remember Yourself | We Can Do Hard Things
item.description: Podcast Description Abby shares with Sara the great personal impact Sara’s music has made on her life. Sara and Glennon bond over the joy of solitude, the underrated gifts of being heavy-hearted, and the fact that “there are too many things to be worried about at all times” to be lighthearted. When you are in deep stress, do you try to sabotage your job, relationship, etc.? (Before this conversation, Amanda thought it was just her.

item.title: 140. Alex Morgan: Believe in Your Own Greatness | We Can Do Hard Things
item.description: Podcast Description How the Abby+Alex sisterhood began, how hard it was for Alex to watch Abby suffer at the end of her career, and how friends can build each other up. How to get back on the field – in life and in sport – after crushing defeat. The way Alex’s mom helped Alex fulfill her dream, and what Alex is teaching her own daughter, Charlie. How Alex finally stopped comparing herself to others and started resting in her own confidence.

item.title: 139. No More Grind: How to Finally Rest with Tricia Hersey | We Can Do Hard Things
item.description: Podcast Description The Nap Ministry’s Nap Bishop shares small, concrete ways to bring rest into our own lives – especially when rest seems impossible. Why so many of us feel like machines instead of humans – and the power of imagination as a spiritual practice to reconnect with our humanity and divinity. Why grind culture – a collaboration of capitalism and white supremacy – wants to keep us exhausted, and how we can resist a culture of overwhelming busy-ness.

item.title: 138. Melissa McCarthy: Sex, Nuns & Ghosts | We Can Do Hard Things
item.description: Podcast Description What Melissa’s parents said when she told them about her dream – and how those magic words set the course of Melissa’s life. The green and red flags Melissa tells her kids to look for in a relationship. Why Melissa is a shark, and her brilliant strategy to “Run Around the Block” in almost any difficult situation. Melissa’s and Abby’s experiences with ghosts. How Melissa learned about sex – and the way she talks to her kids about it.

item.title: 137. Celeste Ng: Why You Feel Stuck | We Can Do Hard Things
item.description: Podcast Description What to do when you’ve done everything you were supposed to do and ended up in a place you don’t want to be. Why the question “What do you want?” is terrifying – and how to start answering it authentically for yourself. The power of imagining what does not yet exist in order to make space for new possibilities. The gift of a “midlife crisis” What a mother’s job really is.

item.title: 136. CARE-FRONTATIONS: Three Keys for Giving & Receiving Criticism | We Can Do Hard Things
item.description: Podcast Description What happens inside us when we receive criticism–and how our brains ensure we’re always in the right (even when we’re not). The three-ingredient recipe for a positive, productive “care-frontation” exchange. The single biggest relationship killer (it’s not conflict) – and how conflict can bring you closer. Amanda navigates a “care-frontation” with her son’s friend’s family – and Abby reevaluates her past relationship with criticism. To learn more about listener data and our privacy practices visit: https://www.

item.title: Introducing: It Was Said Season 2 | We Can Do Hard Things
item.description: Podcast Description It Was Said, the 2021 Webby Award winner for Best Podcast Series, returns with a new season to look back on some of the most powerful, impactful, and timeless speeches in history. Written and narrated by Pulitzer Prize winner and bestselling author-historian Jon Meacham, this documentary podcast series takes you through another season of ten generation-defining speeches. Meacham, along with top historians, authors and journalists, offers expert insight and analysis into the origins, the orator, and the context of the times each speech was given, and they reflect on why it’s important to never forget them.

item.title: 135. Letting Go of How It’s “Supposed to Be” | We Can Do Hard Things
item.description: Podcast Description The twinge of loneliness that comes with searching for what it seems like everyone else has. A Varsity-level question from Christie that challenges everything we said about Help on Tuesday’s episode. How to make “your thing” more of an “our thing” in relationships–and how Abby got Glennon into the sports. If there is anything worse than vacationing with your own kids, it’s vacationing with other people’s kids–and the time Glennon staged a sketchy early exit from a group trip.

item.title: 134. HELP: How to Ask for the Help You Need | We Can Do Hard Things
item.description: Podcast Description Why sharing your messy middle with someone is a gift and connection builder, not a burden. The reasons why we don’t ask for the help we desperately need. “Vague favs” and why are they a hard No for Amanda. Abby, Glennon, and Amanda each share something they need help with right now. The science behind Help as one of the most effective relationship-enhancing tools, and the best ways to finally ask for it.

item.title: 133. Indigo Girls: Sexuality, Sobriety, Faith & Freedom | We Can Do Hard Things
item.description: Podcast Description Why Emily couldn’t stop crying (and it wasn’t because she was emotional). The intervention that got Emily sober – and why Amy wasn’t there. Glennon admits something that she’s never told anyone before. Amy and Abby agree on the shared cost of internalized homophobia and misogyny. About Indigo Girls: One of the most successful folk duos in history – Amy Ray and Emily Sailers aka THE INDIGO GIRLS – has recorded 16 albums and sold over 15 million records.

item.title: 132. Christen Press: How to Get Your Bliss Back | We Can Do Hard Things
item.description: Podcast Description The moment Abby – as Christen’s USWNT roommate – walked into their hotel room and knew Christen was very different than any soccer player she’d ever known. The boundary that helps Christen love her people while protecting herself. Christen’s take on death and how to keep the people we’ve lost alive in our lives. How to show our people (including our little athletes) that we love them for who they are, not what they achieve.

item.title: 131. How to Raise Untamed Kids with Dr. Becky Kennedy | We Can Do Hard Things
item.description: Podcast Description How to embody your authority while also validating your kid’s experience. The #1 strategy for building resilience. Why consequences and punishments backfire and don’t work. How to sit with your child on the “benches” of their emotions. One thing you can say to your kids to build connection in any circumstance. About Dr. Becky: Dr. Becky Kennedy is a clinical psychologist and mom of three, named “The Millennial Parenting Whisperer” by TIME Magazine.

item.title: 130. Breaking Cycles & Reparenting Yourself with Dr. Becky Kennedy | We Can Do Hard Things
item.description: Podcast Description The 3 most important things to say to your kids and partners every day. Why our kids trigger us – and a fail-proof strategy to use when you’re triggered. Why “poorly-behaved kids” can be a sign of good parenting. How to break family cycles by rewiring the way we were raised. How to use Internal Family Systems to heal ourselves. About Dr. Becky: Dr. Becky Kennedy is a clinical psychologist and mom of three, named “The Millennial Parenting Whisperer” by TIME Magazine.

item.title: 129. What Your Sign Says About How You Love: Chani Nicholas | We Can Do Hard Things
item.description: Podcast Description How to recognize when you’re dysregulated – so you can slow down and help yourself. The beauty and wisdom in being judgmental, and how that saved Chani’s life. The liberating idea that “The things that happened to me weren’t about me.” How to set and trust boundaries in order to finally rest. About Chani: Chani Nicholas is a Los Angeles-based New York Times bestselling author of You Were Born For This: Astrology for Radical Self-Acceptance.

item.title: 128. HOW GLENNON LOST HER MIND | We Can Do Hard Things
item.description: Podcast Description “Weird Glennon” comes back to the pod and shares her #1 sanity strategy. The rule Glennon and Abby set for their wedding week that made everything OK. How Amanda stopped accepting assignments from strangers. How Glennon discovered she couldn’t trust her thoughts – and found the part of herself she could trust. How to know if your thinking is disordered, and how to reorient it to be more effective in your life, relationships, and world.

item.title: 127. Are you a Feeler or a Thinker? Either Way, Genius! | We Can Do Hard Things
item.description: Podcast Description An Advocate, Commander, and Entertainer walk into a podcast – and each share how they feel about their labels. Do personality types make you feel boxed in, or give you permission to be you? How to decide when it’s important to work first and play later, or jump on a moment of joy and work later. How Glennon as a strong F (Feeler) and Amanda as a strong T (Thinker) make business decisions together.

item.title: 126. WHAT’S YOUR TYPE? How Personality Shapes Your Life | We Can Do Hard Things
item.description: Podcast Description Our desperate desire to figure out: Why are we the way we are? Why Abby once believed she was 100% extroverted, and the fear she uncovered that makes her think she’s not. How what you think about when you see a cactus tells you a lot about your personality. Why some of the best-known personality binaries are just silly – and corporately manufactured. To learn more about listener data and our privacy practices visit: https://www.

item.title: 125. WHY ARE THERE NO PICTURES OF US?!? | We Can Do Hard Things
item.description: Podcast Description Deep dive into how it feels to not be in any of your family photos, why it happens, and how to change it. A call-in question from a husband that made Amanda cry. Reimagining “acts of service” and how to know whether actions belong in the “Adulting Bucket” or the “Love Bucket.” Getting the kids to read over the summer went terribly, thanks for asking. To learn more about listener data and our privacy practices visit: https://www.

item.title: 124. How to Say No: Boundaries with Nedra Glover Tawwab | We Can Do Hard Things
item.description: Podcast Description Five signs that you might have a boundary problem. Why each of us should stop pretending we’re not a needy person. How to stop arguing like a lawyer – and start communicating like a kindergartener – to get what you need. How to know when to end an argument, how to exit a friendship, and how to respond to passive aggressiveness. About Nedra: Nedra Glover Tawwab, MSW, LCSW, is a New York Times best-selling author, licensed therapist, and sought-after relationship expert.

item.title: 123. Find Your Towanda with Tig Notaro & Stephanie Allynne | We Can Do Hard Things
item.description: Podcast Description Tig and Stephanie’s highly effective and hilarious ways to diffuse their marital feuds. Stephanie’s experience figuring out her sexuality (years after she married Tig)–and how Tig knew Stephanie was the one. Why Tig’s deep in “Towanda-ing” right now–and how that affects their marriage. The power of knowing what you DON’T want in your life. Tig, Stephanie, Abby, and Glennon each share something they’ve discovered they don’t want. About Stephanie: Stephanie Allynne is a writer, actor, producer, and director.

item.title: 122. Why We Should Stop Doing Our Best | We Can Do Hard Things
item.description: Podcast Description Abby’s new nightly ritual of 80’s parties and Amanda’s wild adventure at a crawfish boil. Glennon’s transition out of depression, and how she’s moving off “The Landing.” Why our parents are so triggering – and how we can see them differently. Glennon, Abby, and Amanda answer pressing Pod Squad questions. Amanda pays tribute to a particular Pod Squader, Lexi – and to all women of her generation. To learn more about listener data and our privacy practices visit: https://www.

item.title: 121. Martha Beck & Rowan Mangan: Polyamory & Throuple Life | We Can Do Hard Things
item.description: Podcast Description What is Polyamory – and how Martha, Rowan, and Karen make their relationship work. How Martha felt – after years of marriage to Karen – when Karen told her she was in love with Rowan, too. The hilarious moment Martha, Karen, and Rowan told their friends they were now a throuple. A huge lesson for couples based on the revolutionary ways they deal with conflict, jealousy, and daily rituals to stay close.

item.title: 120. Jen Hatmaker’s Back! Forgiveness & the Audacity to Rebuild | We Can Do Hard Things
item.description: Podcast Description Why Jen believes none of us is safe from betrayal – but how she knows with certainty it will never happen to her again. The useful part of unforgiveness, the worst thing about forgiveness, and how to know when it’s time to forgive. Brené Brown’s advice to Jen for how to begin rebuilding brick by brick after the life you built implodes. The steps Jen took to learn to trust her body for the first time – and what she calls her body now.

item.title: 119. It’s OK to Want What You Want: Cheryl Strayed as Dear Sugar | We Can Do Hard Things
item.description: Podcast Description Pod Squad Qs about co-parenting after infidelity, setting boundaries with friends, and reconciling an estranged parent relationship. How to know when it’s time to leave, and whether your partner deserves to be free of you. Why every problem Cheryl’s ever had has been solved by a list–and how to use her strategy. Ways to be a better advice-giver, and how to keep “floating in the direction of your own life.

item.title: 118. Cheryl Strayed: Don’t Let Your Dreams Ruin Your Life | We Can Do Hard Things
item.description: Podcast Description Why Cheryl chose Strayed as her last name – the only one not given to her by a man. How she ruined her life when her mom died, and how we can bear the unbearable. Cheryl’s greatest lesson from her 3-month hike of the PCT, and her mom’s advice she uses everyday. How to make peace with our ITS – “inner terrible someone” – who lives in each of us.

item.title: 117. How to Love Your Body Now with Carson Tueller | We Can Do Hard Things
item.description: Podcast Description The question Carson’s sister asked that made him radically reimagine his life. Why Carson is having the best sex of his life. How Carson received sign-off from his Mormon Bishop for his first queer date. The accident that left Carson paralyzed from the chest down at 23. How ableism hurts us all. About Carson: Carson Tueller is a coach, speaker and activist whose work provides people with the tools they need to live authentic, fulfilling, and powerful lives.

item.title: 116. Our Most Embarrassing Stories | We Can Do Hard Things
item.description: Podcast Description Glennon, Abby, and Amanda share the most mortifying moments of their lives. Pod Squaders’ hilarious voicemail confessions, which had Glennon, Abby, and Amanda cry-laughing in solidarity. Our new go-to strategy when humiliated (it involves prosthetic penises). We test our hypothesis that sharing our most embarrassing experiences makes us feel less alone. To learn more about listener data and our privacy practices visit: https://www.audacyinc.com/privacy-policy Learn more about your ad choices.

item.title: 115. Chelsea Handler: On Breaking Up & Being Unbreakable | We Can Do Hard Things
item.description: Podcast Description Chelsea Handler comes to We Can Do Hard Things to talk for the first time about her breakup with Jo Koy, her definition of real love, and her commitment to never abandon herself. About Chelsea: Chelsea Handler is a comedian, television host, best-selling author and advocate whose humor and candor have established her as one of the most celebrated voices in entertainment and pop culture. She was the host of E!

item.title: 114. Reese Witherspoon on Friendship: What, Like It’s Hard? | We Can Do Hard Things
item.description: Podcast Description How to make the first friendship move – and how to move on from a friendship with kindness and clarity. The advice Reese passes down to her kids about the three types of people you meet in life. Reese’s Hollywood experience as a young woman – and the solidarity she found in the Time’s Up movement. How Elle Woods – in all her iconic glory – hilariously showed up while Reese was on real-life jury duty.

item.title: 113. The Time Glennon & Abby Called It Off – and Live Pod Squad Q&A! | We Can Do Hard Things
item.description: Podcast Description How horrifying advice from a therapist led Glennon to end things with Abby–and how they reconnected. The moments from past episodes that changed us–including Amanda’s new strategy to prevent her anxiety from creating relationship problems. How we decide what to share publicly and what not to–and why we think the dichotomy of “sacred things” versus “private things” is dangerous. Simple guidance to a man who asks how to stand in the fight for women’s rights, a question from 68-year-old Donna that we can’t stop thinking about, and the story of Tish’s We Can Do Hard Things song.

item.title: 112. Abby’s First Love, G Restarts Recovery, and Amanda Tries Meds: Live Event | We Can Do Hard Things
item.description: Podcast Description Over 15,000 Pod Squaders joined live to celebrate One Year of the Pod and discuss: Why Amanda started taking meds, Glennon keeps taking meds–and why Abby might consider taking meds :) The brilliant preemptive post mortem strategy to help you emotionally recover from any gathering. Your frequently asked question of Abby: How she tracked down her first love connection at the Macaroni Grill. The pie chart of showing up–and why it’s rarely ever 100%.

item.title: 111. Natalie Portman: How to Know When to Say YES | We Can Do Hard Things
item.description: Podcast Description The moment Natalie called Abby to invite her to be part of Angel City FC–the first majority, women-owned soccer franchise. How to stop people-pleasing and learn to recognize a full body YES from inside of you. Why and how Natalie shows up for big projects before she’s ready or qualified. (Dude Moves). The best advice Natalie’s ever received–and why women should “Gossip Well.” How Natalie counters gender expectations by over practicing empathy with her son and decisiveness with her daughter.

item.title: 110. Why Grief – like Love – is Forever with Marisa Renee Lee | We Can Do Hard Things
item.description: Podcast Description Practical tips for guiding friends and family through your grief–and the permission slips to give yourself. 2. Why there is no such thing as grief etiquette–and how it’s less about what you say and more about what you do. What it finally took for Marisa to surrender to the fact that she was not in control of her love or her grief. How to integrate love and grief in order to find joy again after loss–and how, 12 years after her mother’s death, Marisa includes her mom in her son’s life.

item.title: 109. How to Survive This Absurd Life with Samantha Irby | We Can Do Hard Things
item.description: Podcast Description Sam’s life-changing strategies for (reluctantly) interacting with humans. How we use humor to hide the lava of rage churning beneath our surface. Sam’s friendship theory and why she doesn’t need a deep soul connection with every “lowercase f friend.” Sam’s embrace of JOMO (Joy of Missing Out)–and why she genuinely believes no one else is having a better time (except maybe Abby). The behind-the-scenes story of the “Fat Babe Pool Party” Shrill show–and why that episode was one of the most important things she’s ever written.

item.title: 108. ABORTION: Family Meeting on Four Things to Do Next | We Can Do Hard Things
item.description: Podcast Description Pod Squad Family Meeting! To see each other’s rage and grief, talk about how we got here, renew our resolve to fight forward and to take tender care of each other as we do, and to share four concrete steps we can all take to join the fight for reproductive justice. Because what got us here is not going to get us out of here. To learn more about listener data and our privacy practices visit: https://www.

item.title: 107. Billie Jean King: Abby’s Hero Shares Her Hardest Battle | We Can Do Hard Things
item.description: Podcast Description How Billie Jean could not live as her full authentic self until age 51. The moment Billie Jean knew that Abby was not okay after her USWNT retirement. How to visualize a reality that doesn’t yet exist – so you can be it, even when you don’t see it. How Billie Jean numbed herself through an eating disorder and how she recovered by not being a “good girl.” Why Billie Jean does not regret her pre-Roe abortion, and the degrading process she endured to access it.

item.title: 106. Astrology: Your Sign’s Secrets with Heidi Rose Robbins | We Can Do Hard Things
item.description: Podcast Description How Heidi ruined Glennon’s life with a jarring new identity–and why it’s a powerful moment for G to embrace her newfound sign. How we each have a Sun, Moon, and Rising sign–and what each tells us about ourselves. Heidi breaks down the 12 astrological signs–and astrology as a tool for self revelation. Why we keep saying “Mercury’s in retrograde” and what the hell it means. About Heidi: Heidi Rose Robbins has been a professional astrologer for 25 years, helping thousands of clients all over the globe live with more authenticity and clarity.

item.title: 105. Restart Your Sex Life with Dr. Lori Brotto | We Can Do Hard Things
item.description: Podcast Description Answers to fascinating sex questions from Pod Squaders–including how to get real in the bedroom after regularly faking orgasm. Concrete mindfulness strategies to get out of your head and into your body, which have been proven to increase arousal and satisfaction. Busting the myth about how long it should take to orgasm. Why talking about sex (including fantasies!) before having sex leads to more satisfying intimacy–and why that feels fun for Abby and impossible to Glennon and Amanda.

item.title: 104. Orgasm: Pleasure is the Final Frontier with Dr. Lori Brotto2 | We Can Do Hard Things
item.description: Podcast Description The shocking revelation that many women experience physical arousal but can’t reach orgasm because we are so “stuck” in our heads that we don’t even register it. Glennon and Abby share about their periodic sexual droughts – and Dr. Brotto gives them (us) advice. The biggest predictors of sexual problems for women – including stress/compulsive multitasking – and how to address them. How to know if you are disconnecting from your body during sex, and how to reintegrate to increase your pleasure.

item.title: 103. How to Be More Alive with Cole Arthur Riley | We Can Do Hard Things
item.description: Podcast Description In this beautiful conversation–in which Glennon names Cole’s book “This Here Flesh” the Next Right Book–we discuss: What we learned from Cole’s insight that, “If you’re not in your body, someone else is.” A mind-blowing revelation about all of our own faces that we will never stop thinking about. Why the phrase “If you don’t believe you’re beautiful, no one else will” is horseshit. Why dignity is the bedrock to being alive–and how to find it when we haven’t been loved well.

item.title: 102. Ashlyn Harris & Ali Krieger Double Date! | We Can Do Hard Things
item.description: Podcast Description Abby’s former USWNT teammates–and dear friends–Ashlyn Harris and Ali Krieger are here for a double date discussing: Ashlyn and Ali’s wedding, their vision for queer marriage visibility, and Glennon’s top moments of their magical day. Ashlyn and Abby’s friendship–why Ashlyn pulled Abby’s final game captain’s band out of the trash and what she plans to do with it. Who made the first move, which one “knew” first, and how Ashlyn and Ali’s love story started with friendship and mixtapes.

item.title: 101. How to Be the Boss of Yourself with Bozoma Saint John | We Can Do Hard Things
item.description: Podcast Description The inspiring pep talk Bozoma gives herself in the mirror – and why we might all want to start using it to rally ourselves. How to navigate the tightrope of corporate expectations for women: to be both self-assured and humble; both hard and soft. The revolutionary realization that you don’t have to be the savior of others – you can save yourself, too. How to know when to dig deep, and stay and fight for change – and when to stop digging and go – and the moment Bozoma knew it was time to leave Netflix.

item.title: 100. Jenny Lawson is Broken (in the Best Possible Way) | We Can Do Hard Things
item.description: Podcast Description Content warning: Discussion of suicide. Jenny puts words to her experience of ADD – “being a kitten on cocaine” – and her anxiety – seeing “rainbow fire.” How Jenny felt guilty for years about a way her mental illness impacted her mothering – only to later learn it was her child’s favorite memory. The moment she decided to be honest about her struggles – and how sharing our awkwardness can save the world and cure our loneliness.

item.title: 99. How We’ll Save Our Kids From the Gun Lobby’s Greed with Shannon Watts | We Can Do Hard Things
item.description: Podcast Description Why guns are now the leading cause of death for American children and teens, and who is profiting from America’s suffering. What to say today when your child leaves the house to help protect them from gun violence. The lie our leaders are selling us about why they won’t pass the reforms that 90% of Americans want, and how one mom became the NRA’s biggest nightmare. How to safeguard our kids from the negative impact of for-profit active shooter drills in schools.

item.title: 98. How to Live So We Can Die Peacefully with Death Doula Alua Arthur | We Can Do Hard Things
item.description: Podcast Description What Alua has learned about living well from the many people she’s helped walk home as a death doula. The “deathbed test” that guides her toward what is important and helps her stay present. Alua eases Abby’s immense fear of death by sharing her glitter-wave vision. The most surprising thing she wants us to know about death. Concrete steps we can take now to help prepare ourselves–and our loved ones–for the inevitable.

item.title: 97. How Family Secrets Shape Us: Emotional Inheritance with Dr. Galit Atlas | We Can Do Hard Things
item.description: Podcast Description How we are each haunted by our family’s secrets and trauma–whether we know them or not–and how to break the cycle for future generations. The astounding new research on generational trauma showing that our personal trauma is passed down genetically to our children and grandchildren. Our unconscious need to heal what our parents could not–and how to mourn what we cannot control. Why our bodies carry what our mind won’t remember–and how to release that burden.

item.title: 96. Cameron Esposito: How to Save Your Damn Self | We Can Do Hard Things
item.description: Podcast Description Glennon and Abby welcome their dear friend Cameron Esposito to discuss: Cameron’s brutiful relationship with her body–and how it feels playing a sexy TV role. The way Cameron grew up using humor as self-defense and to become socially “valuable”–and the moment she wondered if comedy was no longer working for her. Why Cameron says she’s able to cry for the first time in 35 years. How as a gender-nonconforming queer kid, Cameron felt “overnoticed”–and how being a comedian allows her to “hide in plain sight.

item.title: 95. Why Elizabeth Gilbert Disappeared & What She Came Back to Say | We Can Do Hard Things
item.description: Podcast Description Part Two of our gorgeous conversation with Elizabeth Gilbert: Liz describes Rayya’s death as “a fist fight”–and how Rayya went out swinging. In the wake of Rayya’s death, how Liz grieved, and what helped. Liz’s spiritual practices: communing with a higher power, her recovery community, and starting over. About Elizabeth: Elizabeth Gilbert is author of the international bestseller, EAT PRAY LOVE, which has been translated into over thirty languages, and sold over 12 million copies worldwide.

item.title: 94. Liz Gilbert Shares the Whole Story for the First Time | We Can Do Hard Things
item.description: Podcast Description Part One of our intimate conversation with Elizabeth Gilbert: When Glennon called Liz about Abby–and Liz then told Glennon about Rayya. The moment Liz imploded her life as she knew it. How, after a decade of friendship, Liz finally told Rayya that she was in love with her. The brutal chaos of Rayya’s addiction at the end of her life–and what Liz had to do and say to protect herself.

item.title: 93. BURNOUT: Do You Feel Half Alive? | We Can Do Hard Things
item.description: Podcast Description With everything going on in the world, and in our lives, is “Burnout” the reason we all feel like zombies? Why stress is like trash: You have to get rid of it often or your life starts to stink. Emily and Amelia Nagoski – the authors of Burnout: The Secret to Unlocking the Stress Cycle – answer our Pod Squad’s burning questions about how to bounce back from burnout.

item.title: 92. Chanel Miller Promises: We are Never Stuck | We Can Do Hard Things
item.description: Podcast Description Thinking of depression as a way of seeing the world … through toilet paper roll binoculars. Why healing might actually just be permission to go. Chanel’s definition of success: refusing to succumb to perfection or exhaustion–and showing up as herself in every moment. The healing moment when Chanel returned to Stanford and was held in sound–which set her free. About Chanel: Chanel Miller is a writer and artist who received her BA in Literature from the University of California, Santa Barbara.

item.title: 91. Better Sex & Lives in Menopause with Dr. Jen Gunter | We Can Do Hard Things
item.description: Podcast Description How to get your orgasm back. Dr. Jen Gunter’s advice–and personal mantra–for surviving hot flushes. How to differentiate between mental health challenges and menopause. The one easy thing you can do at the doctor’s office to ensure better care. Is menopause a reboot of the brain and an opportunity to reallocate mental resources? Resource: North American Menopause Society (NAMS) About Jen: Dr. Jen Gunter is an OB/GYN and pain medicine physician and the author of The Menopause Manifesto, The Vagina Bible, and The Preemie Primer.

item.title: 90. Menopause: What We Deserve to Know with Dr. Jen Gunter | We Can Do Hard Things
item.description: Podcast Description Hot flushes, night sweats, sleep disturbances, vaginal dryness, and the less common, frequently-missed symptoms of menopause. A strategy and script for how to talk to your doctor without being dismissed. The lies and truth about menopause hormone therapy. Why our culture is fixated on investing to ensure men never lose their erection, but is fine with women losing their quality of life. What we need to know about our bodies and lives during menopause, which will impact up to 20 years of our lives.

item.title: 89. Enneagram: What does your number say about you? with Ashton Whitmoyer-Ober | We Can Do Hard Things
item.description: Podcast Description What is your Enneagram number–and how does this ancient wisdom explain WHY you do what you do? Why Glennon really didn’t want to accept her Enneagram number, and how she finally saw herself clearly in it. How the Enneagram helps Amanda have much more compassion for herself–and how she uses it to understand common patterns in her marriage. Glennon and Amanda use the Enneagram to dissect what is actually going on in their conflicts, and how to make each other feel seen and understood.

item.title: 88. Brené Brown & Barrett Guillen Sisters Double Date!! | We Can Do Hard Things
item.description: Podcast Description Brené and Barrett share their parenting strategy that Brené calls “the opposite of raising a child that’s full of shame.” The family of origin roles that Brené (the Protector) and Barrett (the Peacekeeper) had to adjust in order to work together–and the two keys to working well with family. The ways in which a child who grows up living on eggshells becomes an adult who is fearful–and how that fear shows up differently for Brené, Barrett, Glennon, and Amanda.

item.title: 87. Jen Hatmaker & Tyler Merritt Double Date! | We Can Do Hard Things
item.description: Podcast Description Jen Hatmaker is back with the new man in her life–actor, author, and activist Tyler Merritt–for a double date with Glennon and Abby discussing: How Jen and Tyler met, what first attracted Jen and Tyler to each other–and who made the first move. How not knowing any “dating rules” led Jen to jumpstart the “define the relationship” step. The triggers for Jen that led to an early relationship “wobble” and how Jen is navigating issues of trust and safety after her divorce.

item.title: 86. Jen Hatmaker: What We Win When We Lose It All | We Can Do Hard Things
item.description: Podcast Description Jen describes the shock of losing her 26-year marriage overnight. How, looking back, Jen sees that she knew something was wrong in her relationship well before she “knew” something was wrong–and the moment she reached out to Glennon to share it for the first time. 3. Why Jen’s friends told her she was a “human spotlight” and “cleanup crew” in her marriage–and the pain of realizing she was powerful in every role other than wife.

item.title: 85. Susan Cain Says Sadness is a Superpower | We Can Do Hard Things
item.description: Podcast Description How to know if you are a “Bittersweet” type. On “stabs of joy”—and why our joy is often accompanied by dread. How to complete the cycle of sadness, in order to live with more joy. Susan and Sister’s best relationship advice: That our longing for the perfect partner is not really about our partner. Why Glennon thinks those who feel the ache are often those who fall into addiction.

item.title: 84. Mothers & Sons with Ocean Vuong (and Chase Melton) | We Can Do Hard Things
item.description: Podcast Description Glennon’s son, Chase, joins Glennon for a special conversation with his hero, author Ocean Vuong, to discuss: Chase shares with Ocean the impact his work has had in his life–and Glennon thanks Ocean for helping mother her son. What Ocean learned from his mother about how to navigate being an Asian boy in America–and Glennon’s recognition that she did not prepare Chase for the same realities. Ocean’s new book, Time is a Mother, and why watching his own mother die gave Ocean a deep empathy and connection to every person.

item.title: 83. Brené Brown: What to Say to Get What You Need | We Can Do Hard Things
item.description: Podcast Description How to know when to dig deep–and when to quit digging. The greatest blocker of connection–and how to remove it. How to handle our fear (without obsessively controlling our people and our environment). Why we all deserve a standing ovation for navigating relationships over the past two years. About Brené: Dr. Brené Brown is a research professor at the University of Houston where she holds the Huffington Foundation Endowed Chair at The Graduate College of Social Work.

item.title: 82. Hannah Gadsby: How to Communicate Better | We Can Do Hard Things
item.description: Podcast Description Why Hannah describes her later-in-life Autism Spectrum Disorder diagnosis as “an exfoliation of shame.” How neurodiversity affects Hannah’s relationships–and how she connects to the world through what’s “interesting” instead of what’s “important.” Hannah’s revolutionary commitment to stop using self-deprecating humor about her body, sexuality, and gender–and why we might all consider the same commitment. Why it’s easier for Hannah to share her personal stories “in bulk” on stage instead of one-on-one.

item.title: 81. Pro-Aging: Why the Best is Yet to Come with Ashton Applewhite. | We Can Do Hard Things
item.description: Podcast Description Why we’ve been sold a lie–and the truth that we actually get happier the older we get! The two most important–and shocking–predictors of aging well. Busting the most prevalent misconceptions and about getting older. How believing the myths about aging literally harms our health and makes us more vulnerable to the fears we hold about aging. Glennon paints a mental picture of her older self–and encourages the Pod Squad to do the same.

item.title: 80. This is 46: Why I’m Pumped About Midlife | We Can Do Hard Things
item.description: Podcast Description How Glennon is using her 46th birthday as an intermission–to slow down and decide what to bring with her into Act 2. The counterculture power of knowing what is enough, and letting ourselves go. The way to transition from Role Living to Soul Living–and why Glennon has Joni Mitchell on repeat. The real meaning of “crisis”–and the idea that living well now means reimagining everything we learned in the first half of life.

item.title: 79. The Power of Rethinking Everything with Dr. Yaba Blay | We Can Do Hard Things
item.description: Podcast Description Why the construct of beauty is oppressive, but the essence of beauty is freedom. What living with integrity looks like. Why Dr. Blay doesn’t need any more allies—and what she really wants from an accomplice. How “Karens” have been around for centuries—and the direct line from “Miss Anne to Karen.” Dr. Blay’s greatest hope for her granddaughters—even if she doesn’t like it. item.title: 78. REGRET: What if we’d done things differently? | We Can Do Hard Things
item.description: Podcast Description Amanda shares the biggest regret of her life: the one that still wakes her up in the middle of the night. The five biggest regrets of the dying—and how to make the necessary changes to avoid them. Why we should reframe regret as proof of a life well-lived. item.title: 77. Double Date with Brandi & Catherine Carlile! | We Can Do Hard Things
item.description: Podcast Description In this hilarious and heartwarming in-person double date with Abby and Glennon—and their dear friends and brilliant artists Brandi and Catherine Carlile—we learn: Why Brandi was completely dismayed the first time she met Catherine; Who made the first move—and why it made Catherine sweat; All about the Carlile family compound—where they are raising their girls surrounded by family, band members, and exes; How they communicate and deal with jealousy; and Why Brandi believes this conversation—two queer couples sitting on a couch publicly discussing marriage, family, and domesticity—is revolutionary.

item.title: 76. Brandi Carlile: Live From My Couch! | We Can Do Hard Things
item.description: Podcast Description The two disagreements between Brandi and Glennon that started, and cemented, their friendship. Brandi’s lifelong quest to continuously “calibrate” herself so that her outsides are in tune with her insides. The trait Brandi loves most about Catherine—and the sticky note on Glennon’s desk with the same message. About Brandi: Brandi Carlile is a six-time GRAMMY Award-winning singer, songwriter, performer, producer, #1 New York Times Bestselling author and activist, who is known as one of music’s most respected voices.

item.title: 75. ALOK: How do we interrupt trauma? How do we heal? | We Can Do Hard Things
item.description: Podcast Description How do we make a new thing with our life? What is your fingerprint on the world? Who does history try to erase and why? What does pain do to our bodies? 5 .What is our capacity for transformation? About ALOK: ALOK (they/them) is an internationally acclaimed writer, performer, and public speaker. As a mixed-media artist their work explores themes of trauma, belonging, and the human condition. They are the author of Femme in Public (2017), Beyond the Gender Binary (2020), and Your Wound/My Garden (2021).

item.title: 74. ALOK: What makes us beautiful? What makes us free? | We Can Do Hard Things
item.description: Podcast Description “The days that I feel most beautiful are the days that I am most afraid.” “What feminine part of yourself did you have to destroy in order to survive in this world?” “Why have we been taught to fear the very things that can set us free?” About ALOK: ALOK (they/them) is an internationally acclaimed writer, performer, and public speaker. As a mixed-media artist their work explores themes of trauma, belonging, and the human condition.

item.title: 73. Pet Love: Are Animals the Closest We Come to Unconditional Love? | We Can Do Hard Things
item.description: Podcast Description Amanda shares the story of Séamus, the newest addition to her family–and how he has ruined her “religion” of the spreadsheet. Why Glennon says that Honey and Hattie are the only “people” who truly understand her–and what each of them teach her about love. The ways we hilariously project emotions onto our pets–and how Abby has fallen for Tish’s pet hamster, Biscuit. To learn more about listener data and our privacy practices visit: https://www.

item.title: 72. Double Date with Megan Rapinoe & Sue Bird! | We Can Do Hard Things
item.description: Podcast Description For their first (of hopefully many) podcast double dates, Abby and Glennon sit down with the icons, activists, and Olympians Megan Rapinoe and Sue Bird. In this honest and hilarious conversation, we find out: The delightfully awkward moment Megan and Sue first met; What’s hard for each of them right now; The boundaries they’re working on together; How they communicate and deal with jealousy; and How they help each other show up in the world as champions for change.

item.title: 71. Be Messy, Complicated & Afraid–and Show Up Anyway | We Can Do Hard Things

Abby’s struggle, as a bonus parent, adjusting to a kid-filled life with zero personal space and personal property boundaries. item.title: 68. SARAH PAULSON IS PLAYING GLENNON ON TV!! | We Can Do Hard Things
item.description: Podcast Description Glennon reenacts her first emotional and hilarious email exchange with Sarah Paulson about the Untamed TV show. Sarah contemplates how she will prepare for the role of Glennon–and why she’s “never been more excited about anything truly ever. ” Glennon, Sarah and Abby discuss who will play Abby–and how they will recreate the “There She Is” moment. About Sarah: Sarah Paulson’s acting work includes lead roles in FX’s anthology series “American Horror Story,” and playing Marcia Clark in “The People v.

item.title: 67. How to Get More Joy with Martha Beck | We Can Do Hard Things
item.description: Podcast Description Why it’s important to prioritize our own needs, wants, and feelings–and how that creates freedom and peace for those we love. What Glennon says was the hardest thing about telling her kids that Craig and she were getting a divorce–and how truth telling frees us all. Martha’s helpful strategy for how to choose freedom over fear when we’re faced with a tough decision. About Martha: Dr. Martha Beck is a New York Times bestselling author, life coach, and speaker.

item.title: 66. How to Come Home to Yourself with Martha Beck | We Can Do Hard Things
item.description: Podcast Description How do we tap back into living by our inner compass after living by consensus and following outer voices for so long? What Martha said to Glennon and Abby when they told her they were in love but scared to move forward—and how that advice changed their lives. How to make a plan to cultivate joy when it feels like you are army-crawling through life. About Martha: Dr. Martha Beck is a New York Times bestselling author, life coach, and speaker.

item.title: 65. How Do We Make–and Keep–Good Friends? | We Can Do Hard Things
item.description: Podcast Description How chronic social isolation throughout the pandemic has impacted our friendships–and why that’s affecting our mental health and cravings for connection. Glennon, Amanda, and Abby each make a Next Right Thing plan for prioritizing friendship in their lives. How we grieve a friendship ending when there’s no cultural template or ritual to acknowledge that deep loss. To learn more about listener data and our privacy practices visit: https://www.audacyinc.com/privacy-policy

item.title: 64. FRIENDSHIP: What is it and why do we need it now more than ever? | We Can Do Hard Things
item.description: Podcast Description Why the connection of friendship is emerging as the single best thing for your wellness—and three things that define a healthy friendship. How friendship has changed for Abby since retiring from soccer—and why Glennon fears commitment in friendships more than other relationships. How to recognize ambivalent relationships—and why they can be just as bad for us as toxic ones. CW // eating disorders To learn more about listener data and our privacy practices visit: https://www.

item.title: 63. How to Live a Little Happier with Dr. Laurie Santos | We Can Do Hard Things
item.description: Podcast Description The simple exercises Laurie conducts with her students at Yale to help them reset their brains and restructure their days in order to access happiness. Why being “time famished” is one of the most common obstacles to happiness, the signals our bodies give us that we are starved of unstructured time, and what we can do to build more of it. How understanding that our brains are wired as “comparison machines” incompatible with happiness can lead to improved wellbeing.

item.title: 62. The Big Lies & the Truth About Happiness with Dr. Laurie Santos | We Can Do Hard Things
item.description: Podcast Description One easy thing we can do to increase our happiness by 1% when we’re feeling tired and overwhelmed. Our misconception that happiness is about our circumstances–the next promotion, the new relationship–and the reality that often people with fantastic circumstances are miserable. Why our emotions flow directly from our thoughts–and how we can improve our wellbeing by changing our mind’s interpretation of events. About Laurie: Dr. Laurie Santos is Professor of Psychology and Head of Silliman College at Yale University.

item.title: 61. Are Your Friendships Draining or Charging You? with Luvvie Ajayi Jones | We Can Do Hard Things
item.description: Podcast Description How do we build a squad of friends–people we can trust our truth and imperfection with, and who take responsibility for one another’s care? How to know when it’s time to let a friendship go–and how we release one another without the hard feelings. Why when we have a problem trusting others, it sometimes has to do with a lack of trust in ourselves. Why Luvvie says her friends have rewired her brain, and answers the question: Can Black and white women really be friends?

item.title: 60. Telling the Truth of Who We Are with Luvvie Ajayi Jones | We Can Do Hard Things
item.description: Podcast Description A hilarious, profound take on judging people, and why Luvvie’s telling the world–and has often told Glennon–to: “Fix your face.” How to prepare for hard conversations with those we love–including the lists Luvvie brings to those talks that help keep her calm and vulnerable. The importance of sitting with the fear behind the questions: “Who am I when I am not giving something to somebody?” and “What is my worth when I have nothing to offer?

item.title: 59. Be Still: How to Listen to That Something Inside That Always Knows | We Can Do Hard Things
item.description: Podcast Description What if we stop trying to figure out whether our feelings and intuition are “right” or “wrong”– and instead, just acknowledge them as real–and move toward them? How Glennon is experiencing a little shift in peace, joy, and non-reactivity through her newfound relationship with meditation. Why a lot of our suffering exists in the space between the Knowing and the Doing–and how life is at its best and most exciting when we shorten that gap.

item.title: 58. New Year, Same You: Good News About Bad January Branding | We Can Do Hard Things
item.description: Podcast Description Why do we spend our lives trying to become what our culture ascribes as “good” only to burn ourselves out, wake up, and realize: I thought it would all be more beautiful than this? Why Glennon says that stillness has been her greatest teacher–and how she was able to find it in her most rock bottom moments. How listening for and committing to the next right thing then leads us to the next thing–and why we should rush towards whatever looks and feels like freedom.

item.title: 57. Walking Our People Through Hard Things with Kate Bowler | We Can Do Hard Things
item.description: Podcast Description What we should STOP saying to people who are struggling—and what to say, or do, instead. How Kate received the support she needed because people were willing to embarrass themselves in their attempts to show up—and why we shouldn’t be scared of doing it wrong. Kate offers some words to a Pod Squader feeling anticipatory grief—and how to accept that we can’t always make it okay for the people we love.

item.title: 56. What to Do with Our Short, Precious Life with Kate Bowler | We Can Do Hard Things
item.description: Podcast Description Kate describes the overwhelming feeling of love—not anger—that she felt when she was sure she was near death. Why it’s time we throw out expressions like “Everything is possible” and “What doesn’t kill you, makes you stronger,” and rewrite our cultural cliches. Why Kate delights in celebrating the holidays—and how to survive the holiday season when there’s grief and loss and fear in all of us. Kate and Glennon bond over their love for swear words—and how using them is a reflection of what’s going on inside of them.

item.title: 55. Eff Perfection: Let’s Rest in the Rubble Together | We Can Do Hard Things
item.description: Podcast Description What if we deleted the picture in our head of how it’s “supposed to be,” and looked at “what is” right now, as enough? What makes a good apology–and why we shouldn’t pretend that it is possible to reorder what we did to people. Glennon describes “the ache”–and how it’s really love, coming and going, and making life more beautiful. To learn more about listener data and our privacy practices visit: https://www.

item.title: 54. Unexpected Joy: How do we redefine success so we can find joy? | We Can Do Hard Things
item.description: Podcast Description Glennon, Abby, and Amanda share how opening up and being vulnerable on the podcast has changed their lives. What your preparation style says about your personality—and how some people bring their “magic” while others bring index cards. Abby recalls “the biggest bomb of her life”—and why she was nervous to join Glennon and Amanda on We Can Do Hard Things. To learn more about listener data and our privacy practices visit: https://www.

item.title: 53. How to Love Yourself & Let Yourself be Loved with Ashley C. Ford | We Can Do Hard Things
item.description: Podcast Description Why Ashley says we have to talk about what hurts if we’re ever going to heal. Glennon asks Ashley about the power of apologizing—and why Ashley says we must begin apologizing to the people we love. How many of us are really good at loving other people, but often struggle to let ourselves be loved. Why Ashley says that nothing has ever given her more peace and power than knowing that she doesn’t really need others to believe in her—because she believes so deeply in herself.

item.title: 52. FORGIVING & FINDING PEACE with ASHLEY C. FORD | We Can Do Hard Things
item.description: Podcast Description How to find a way to live in peace: to actually love complicated parents without compromising our love for ourselves. How we can’t change our past—and why Ashley says that forgiveness is accepting the fact that the past is never going to be different. The importance of being able to hold two truths at the same time: that, for some of us, our parents did the best they could—and it wasn’t close to good enough.

item.title: 51. First Ever Live Q & A with the Pod Squad! | We Can Do Hard Things
item.description: Podcast Description Why embracing that it’s not possible to do everything brings freedom. One change that Amanda made to get back into her body and reclaim her fire. How to navigate our anxieties about the impending “return to normal” and how to hold onto the rhythm many of us have found comforting during the pandemic. How Glennon’s been rethinking her popular Untamed quote “The braver I am, the luckier I get.

item.title: 50. GET UNTAMED (Live!): This is How You Find Yourself | We Can Do Hard Things
item.description: Podcast Description What Tish said when asked, “Who has taught you the most about love?”— why it was the best day of Abby’s life, and led her to redefine what it means to be a mother. Glennon declares herself a great adventurer, without movement: an inner travel guide—and how the new journal will help steer us toward our next right thing. How the pandemic brought Amanda’s anxieties, traumas, and relational cracks, previously on a slow burn, to center stage—and what she’s learning from “Be Still and Know.

item.title: 49. Dr. Brené Brown: On Holding Boundaries & Facing Our Fear | We Can Do Hard Things
item.description: Podcast Description 1. Brené and Glennon role play through a scenario on how to put boundaries in practice with family members this holiday season. 2. Why Brené insists that starting “a love affair with the thing you’re most afraid of” will change your life. 3. Glennon asks Brené the question she’s been dying to ask about how a woman’s work is defined and received in the world compared to her male counterparts.

item.title: 48. DR. BRENÉ BROWN: How to Know Ourselves & Be Known by Our People | We Can Do Hard Things
item.description: Podcast Description Why Brené’s new book ATLAS OF THE HEART is a game changer for communicating hard emotions more easily. Brené breaks down the difference between stressed and overwhelmed—and gives us tools to navigate both. How our survival strategies from our families of origin can become both our superpowers and our stumbling blocks in our relationships and wellness. How we can make sure our kids experience deep, steady belonging—even if they don’t feel like they “belong” out in the world.

item.title: 47. YOUR HOLIDAY PEP TALK: “We ask no questions of this day.” | We Can Do Hard Things
item.description: Podcast Description Glennon gives you a beautiful Thanksgiving pep talk that has Amanda and Abby nodding along and rolling with laughter. Why Amanda suggests that we can be free to be our full selves at the Thanksgiving table, if we also each bring our own damn casserole. Why the best predictor of how a family member is going to act is how a family member has always acted. We’re taking holiday-themed questions from our beloved Pod Squad about in-laws, when to break tradition, and how to navigate different family of origin patterns.

item.title: 46. HAPPYISH HOLIDAYS: Our Top Three Hacks | We Can Do Hard Things
item.description: Podcast Description How our second holiday hack—“Be unsurprised”—eliminates walking on eggshells around family, and leaving holiday gatherings feeling badly about ourselves or our people. Amanda shares the first time she broke her family’s biggest holiday tradition—and how it’s now one of her most precious memories. Abby remembers watching her mom stress out by preparing and perfecting every holiday detail—and the change she made to minimize her own holiday stress. How carrying around a cup of hot tea serves as Glennon’s super shield.

item.title: 45. RUNNERS & CHEERERS: Marathon Life with Shalane Flanagan | We Can Do Hard Things
item.description: Podcast Description How a marathon is an analogy for life: the danger of comparison, the ride of emotions and self-doubt, that love is fuel, and that the world needs both runners and cheerers. The question Abby kept asking herself throughout the race—and why she’s still wearing her marathon medal while doing the dishes and running errands. Why race day was so profound to Glennon— even though she is strongly committed to NOT running—and how she experienced her first sports injury while cheering.

item.title: 44. GABRIELLE UNION: Infertility, Bonus Parents & Free Families | We Can Do Hard Things
item.description: Podcast Description Gabrielle shares—as rawly and honestly as we’ve ever heard—about the “emotional chaos” of her years experiencing miscarriage, infertility, and surrogacy. Gabrielle and Abby discuss the label and perception of “stepmom”—Gabrielle shares what she avoids at all costs in that role, and the most vital part of the role for her: consistency. How Gabrielle coached her NBA husband Dwyane before Zaya shared with him that she is gay, and how his reaction encouraged Zaya to tell the people on her “never-ever” list.

item.title: 43. Esther Perel Answers Your Relationship Questions | We Can Do Hard Things
item.description: Podcast Description Why Esther often recommends letter writing if you don’t know quite how to start—or have—hard conversations. What to say—and when to say it—to show up for a friend who is in a bad relationship. The importance of rituals in transitioning through breakups—what we should do when it’s time to say goodbye; and what we can do if we’ve never gotten the closure we need. About Esther Perel: Psychotherapist and New York Times bestselling author Esther Perel is recognized as one of today’s most insightful and original voices on modern relationships.

item.title: 42. ARE YOUR RELATIONSHIPS ALIVE? with Esther Perel | We Can Do Hard Things
item.description: Podcast Description How, if you have been struggling in your romantic, parental, family, or work relationships through the lingering uncertainty of the last two years, you are not alone. The revolutionary understanding that, in relationships, “behind every criticism is a longing; behind every anger is a hurt.” What to do when your relationship is a bond of co-parenting / life management instead of a partnership of ongoing discovery. The link between trauma recovery and the process of enlivening “dead” relationships.

item.title: 41. LANDING IN LOVE: Is the settling-in phase the best stage of love? | We Can Do Hard Things
item.description: Podcast Description How Glennon and Abby transitioned from the “falling in love” phase to “landing in love” at different times—and how Glennon felt “bamboozled” by it. How the self-inflicted guilt of pursuing joy ruins everything. Why a precious gift from Abby made Glennon feel like she’d finally landed in the right galaxy. How the things about our partners that drive us nuts are the same things that attracted us to them.

item.title: 40. FALLING IN LOVE: Is there really “the one” or is “the one” YOU? | We Can Do Hard Things
item.description: Podcast Description Why “falling in love” feels like you’re losing your mind—and Amanda’s experience when Glennon fell hard for Abby. Why Abby thinks the idea of “the one” is the most romantic way to live, and why Amanda thinks “the one” is unromantic and uninteresting. Glennon’s belief that loves are like plants: some loves are perennials that continue to bloom, others are annuals, full for a season and then back to earth to nourish soil—but that no love is ever, ever wasted.

item.title: 39. Passion, Praise & Getting Personal | We Can Do Hard Things
item.description: Podcast Description Glennon makes a “pod-pology”—and why we should stop saying, “I can’t imagine.” Amanda makes the case for no longer praising people as “superheroes”—and why we should stop giving them lip service and bring them a sandwich instead. How we abandon things we love because the environments surrounding them are unbearable—and how to recreate the environment and reclaim what we love. Amanda’s reaction to her new role opening up on the podcast—and how she feels like the very intimate stories she shares are “not personal at all.

item.title: 38. HOW TO SAY NO with Simone Biles and Laurie Hernandez | We Can Do Hard Things
item.description: Podcast Description HOW TO SAY NO with Simone Biles and Laurie Hernandez In this very special conversation, three GOATs and Glennon discuss: What we can learn from Simone’s revolutionary decision at the Tokyo Olympics to choose her physical and mental health over the world’s expectations of her. The tiny decisions that helped Laurie practice trusting herself again after surviving a toxic coach. Why Simone, Laurie, and Abby believe their talent is both a blessing and a curse.

item.title: 37. Creativity, Chemistry & Claiming Your Joy | We Can Do Hard Things
item.description: Podcast Description How Amanda’s breaking point—when her life felt like all “shoulds” and no “wants”—led to simple, concrete changes. Why the labels put upon us early—the sporty one, the smart one, the artsy one—can shut us off from exploring other parts of ourselves. How Glennon feels like Ben Affleck in Good Will Hunting—and why she wants Amanda to “go see about a girl.” What the chemistry of fire has to teach us about how we can resurrect our Fun selves.

item.title: 36. WRITING & ART: When does your real self get to breathe and be seen? | We Can Do Hard Things
item.description: Podcast Description How writing is a lifeline for Glennon because it’s the one place her real self can tell the truth. Why Abby feels that her time on the soccer field was art. The unorthodox way Glennon’s writing evolved from hourly 5AM sessions to survive sobriety with three young kids to three New York Times Best Sellers. Why it’s horseshit that books by women authors are indiscriminately labeled “self-help.” To learn more about listener data and our privacy practices visit: https://www.

item.title: 35. UNBOUND with Tarana Burke—Part 2 | We Can Do Hard Things
item.description: Podcast Description We’re continuing our conversation with activist, founder of the me too movement, and our personal friend and hero,Tarana Burke. We talk about: What Tarana would say to her twelve-year-old self that might have changed the trajectory of her life. Tarana’s life-shifting realization that her relationship struggles with her mother were not due to her mother’s lack of desire to love her well, but her lack of capacity—and how Tarana built more capacity for her own child.

item.title: 34. UNBOUND with Tarana Burke—Part 1 | We Can Do Hard Things
item.description: Podcast Description Please join us in the first part of our joyful, energizing, and hopeful conversation with activist, advocate, and our personal hero,Tarana Burke. We talk about: How the spoken and unspoken rules for girls led Tarana to constantly perform the role of “good girl” so that “her secret” would never be revealed. The impossible double bind so many survivors live through: that the protection of our community is what saves us, but the need to protect our community is what silences us.

item.title: 33. Living by Your Own Original Music Instead of Crappy Cover Tunes | We Can Do Hard Things
item.description: Podcast Description Why Glennon believes the bravest thing she’s ever done was marching into her counselor’s office in high school—and what made her finally say, “I’m not leaving until I get some help.” How we can identify the difference between our Knowing versus our anxiety and conditioning. Why Glennon describes herself as Dory from Nemo, and how she returned to meditation when her mind became unmanageable. To learn more about listener data and our privacy practices visit: https://www.

item.title: 32. BEING BRAVE: What does it take to REALLY be Brave? | We Can Do Hard Things
item.description: Podcast Description The story that led to Abby’s iconic haircut—how that decision terrified her, changed how she played the game, and changed how she lives her life. How Abby and Glennon view “brave” differently—and why Amanda believes their perspectives may be more similar than they think. Why for Amanda the bravest decisions feel like “lonely certainty” that can never be explained or defended to others. To learn more about listener data and our privacy practices visit: https://www.

item.description: Podcast Description We’re back with author and sex educator, Emily Nagoski, taking our Pod Squad’s questions about sex. How to navigate a relationship when one partner has a lower sex drive and the other has a higher sex drive. The “sleepy hedgehog” practice Emily suggests to help partners find their way back to each other after months (or years) of not having sex. How to raise our kids in a more sex-positive family culture.

item.title: 30. REAL, JOYFUL SEX with Emily Nagoski | We Can Do Hard Things
item.description: Podcast Description We welcome our very first guest, author and sex educator Emily Nagoski, who talks with us about how to finally build true, joyful, confident sex lives: How our sex issues are totally normal—we’re all worrying about the same things. Why more than 75% of women do not orgasm from penetration alone—and why Glennon thinks the world doesn’t want us to know that. The single factor that is most predictive of strong sustained sexual connection over time.

item.description: Podcast Description Why Abby says that people pleasing is both her superpower and her Achilles heel. item.title: 26. SEXUAL DESIRE: How do we know who and what we really want? | We Can Do Hard Things
item.description: Podcast Description How Abby discovered she was gay while out to dinner with her parents at a Macaroni Grill. The moment Glennon knew for sure she was queer (in an Amish Boogie Nights bathroom)—and the song that sealed the deal. How, as a straight, cis woman, Amanda never had to wrestle with her sexuality, why she thinks that stunted her exploration. How Glennon’s failed Van Gogh visit inspired Amanda’s next sex steps.

item.title: 25. You’re NOT A MESS. The world is. | We Can Do Hard Things
item.description: Podcast Description The viral note Glennon wrote to herself in her car this week—and how the world’s response confirmed that we’re all struggling right now. How we tend to either Avoid the world’s pain or Be Consumed by it—and how to survive the overwhelm by embracing the Third Way. What Glennon fears most as her oldest child leaves for college. Why we can’t let the fact that we can’t fix everything keep us from doing something—and how Together Rising began.

item.title: 24. ALL THE FEELS: Can we experience our emotions—not as good or bad—but as information to guide us? | We Can Do Hard Things
item.description: Podcast Description Glennon describes how she’s feeling as her oldest leaves for college—and the survival strategy that’s getting her through. The life secret someone told Glennon in early sobriety that changed her life. Amanda discusses the only two strategies that are proven to help us cope with our emotions and become more resilient. How hard feelings always reveal something to you about you. How the life hack Glennon calls “Save as Drafts” has saved her relationships.

item.title: 22. REAL TALK: How can we begin to use conversation as a key to unlocking each other? | We Can Do Hard Things
item.description: Podcast Description Five communication ideas that might help us connect more deeply with people. How Glennon feels that “everyone is talking but nobody is listening to each other ever” and why that’s one of the reasons most of us feel lonely. The conversation strategy that Glennon and Abby use at the dinner table with their kids and friends. Why we love talking about ourselves—and when it helps (and when it hurts) our relationships.

item.description: Podcast Description Glennon lets f-ing loose about the misogyny in our cursing lexicon—and how it reveals our hidden conditioning. (Note: Don’t listen with the kiddos.) item.title: 20. PLAYING OUR ROLES: How does culture’s invention of gender typecast every last one of us? | We Can Do Hard Things
item.description: Podcast Description How, in the business world, Amanda is labeled as aggressive and dominant—and why that’s a gender trap. Abby’s experiences of being publicly misgendered—and how that makes her feel. Why is gender the last place we’re agreed it’s acceptable to make identity assumptions? Why do we tell people who they are before they’re even born—and a thousand different ways every day after? Why Glennon says two women in a marriage, handling their own business, rocks the patriarchal boat.

Why is half the population’s face allowed to exist as is, while the rest of our faces “need” to be covered in concealers, colors, botox, etc.

item.title: We Can Do Hard Things Podcast Premieres Tuesday, May 11th! | We Can Do Hard Things
item.description: Podcast Description Introducing We Can Do Hard Things with Glennon Doyle! I’m Glennon Doyle, author of Untamed – the book that was released at the very start of the pandemic and became a lifeline for millions. I watched in awe from my home while this simple phrase from Untamed - WE CAN DO HARD THINGS – the mantra that saved my life twenty years ago, became a worldwide rally cry. Here, on WE CAN DO HARD THINGS, my sister, Amanda - my best friend and the person I go to all my hard things – and I will do the only thing I’ve ever found that has ever made life easier: We will drop the fake and talk honestly about the hard.
